Title: $\gcd(p_{n-1}, \ n^5 - n^3 + n^2 - n + 1) = 1$ where $p_n = n$th prime.
Content:
How can I prove in general that, for all $n\geq 2$: $$
\gcd(p_{n-1}, \ n^5 - n^3 + n^2 - n + 1) = 1
$$ Seems to always be true: from sympy import *
from sympy.ntheory.generate import prime


def f(n):
    return n**5 - n**3 + n**2 - n +  1

for n in range(3, 100000000):
    p = prime(n-1)
    d = gcd(f(n), p)
    if d != 1:
        print (n) Assume true. $$
f(X) = X^5 - X^3 + X^2 - X + 1
$$ is irreducible and modulo each prime, i.e. $f(n+1) \neq 0 \pmod {p_n}$ so that $\prod_{j=2}^n\overline{f(j+1)} \in $ the units of $\Bbb{Z}/2 \times \Bbb{Z}/3 \times \Bbb{Z}/5 \times \dots $ So far it seems like the polynomials $g(X) = f(X \pm 1)$ are such that $g(n) \neq 0 \pmod {p_n}$
AcceptedAnswer: Comment: Too long for a comment: We can construct $P_{n-1}$ which meets the condition. We can write: $n^5-n^3+n^2-n+1=n^5+n^4(n-1)-\frac{n^6-1}{n-1}\space\space\space \space(1)$ It can be shown that for any $m \in \mathbb N$ and $a>1$ : $\big(\frac {a^m-1}{a-1}, a-1\big)=(a-1, m)\space\space\space \space(2)$ Now with following restrictions we try to construct a prime using relation (1): $\begin {cases}(n, n-1)=1\\(n, 6)=1\end{cases}$ In this way $P_{n-1}$ can have following form: $P_{n-1}=(n-1)(n)(6)+ k; k\in \mathbb Z\space\space\space \space(3)$ Examples: $n=29\rightarrow P_{28}=4872+ k$ For $k=+5$ we get $P_{28}=4877$ Note that $4877$ is not nth prime in the table of prime numbers. It only shows its relation with relation (1). $n=41\rightarrow P_{40}=9840+k$ For $k=-1$ we get $P_{40}=9839$ This can be get for  any n: $n=10\rightarrow P_{9}=540+1=541$ $n=13\rightarrow P_{12}=936+1=937$
